title-group.article-title: A New Test of the Administered Pricing Hypothesis with Canadian Data

abstract.p: In this paper we study the dynamics of price behavior in concentrated and unconcentrated industries during different phases of post-World War II business fluctuations in Canada. We use a nonparametric test to compare, for the period 1948-75, time series of Canadian Industrial Selling Price Indexes from concentrated and less concentrated industries with a series composed entirely of random changes as a base. The use of a random-difference series as a proxy for business-cycle activity is supported by theoretical and empirical work involving rational expectations and efficient information processing in output markets. The use of time-series techniques makes our results somewhat difficult to interpret, but generally they are not inconsistent with one version of the administered pricing hypothesis.
